print_settings.Notes:: Really a simple print, just long.
print_settings.Printer:: R1 ABS + PLA Model

description.text: It works -- it's not pretty, not super strong, it won't fit every reel and rod but it is functional for what I made it for. For now I just strap the holder on to my fishing/kayaking pdf vest with zip ties. I printed it using PLA; soon i will try an ABS print. This will not fit all reels/rods and has a long print (close to 10 hours). It does fit my 6 foot 5/6 wt rod and reel and my 9 foot bamboo rod (which I use the same reel for). It does not however fit my 9 foot 7-8 wt rod/reel.

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Really a simple print, just long.

I did break it!

In my defense however -- I was doing a sweep roll in a kayak without a rod but the holder was still on my pfd. Then I intentionally capsized again, exited the kayak and did what is called a cowboy re-entry. Somewhere during all of this the scoop that holds the reel snapped off.
To hold my rod so I could tie on a new fly or tippet the holder worked fine. As long as it can fit your rod and you're not flipping around in kayaks it should work. The next one I print will be ABS, and I intend to mount it with the zip ties both going up and down instead of perpendicular. A small turn nob for the reel tension often got snagged on one of the zip ties.
Brush Pot
It can be printed in a 3D printer. Two characters (W and U) are embedded in the pot.
Just a fun little cup that's a easy print. i wanted something for my desk to hold coins in so i designed this little dude.
scale in the Z direction(vertical) to 80mm.

title: Rostock Max v2 Layer Fan Mount

description.text:
1/12/17: I created a new lower profile fan mount to work with this e3dv6 mount: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1064131

This is a layer fan designed to keep the fan close to the hot end platform because the stock layer fan mount interfered with the enclosure I made. There is no hardware to use; simply slide it over a hot end platform tab. I have an E3Dv6 on my printer and it protrudes about 5/8" below the platform tabs. I have this mount going 1/2" below the tab it mounts on at a 20° angle to the hot end. It flows a good stream of air and I keep the fan at 80% because I don't want too much air flow interfering with the nozzle's temperature. I included a step file in case you wanted to modify anything for your own setup.

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.25mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

I recommend ABS and I had to scale to 102% due to shrinkage. I printed it as it was imported and used supports only inside the fan pocket and the overhang. I did not use supports on the interior cavity because they would have been difficult to remove.

You might be able to print it on its side and just bridge over the cavity; however, the fan pocket will still need to be supported.

So boring, its perfect! Designed in Tinkercad, this cube is my test print for experimental print settings, new materials and calibration. Its dimensions are 10mmx10mmx10mm. Its volume is 1mL, Duh!
Great for beginners, repeat often to know your printer is working perfectly

• Write down the settings you used to build the G Code
  • Print and mark with letter to note print settings
  • Record print time, surface finish, weight and how close it is to 10mm in all directions
  • Print again to determine your printers precision/repeatability.
    • Its just good to keep track of these things. Its SCIENCE!

title: Whoopee - Tiny Whoop alike frame for 8.5mm Motors
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Please read my post about this frame first, it explain how this frame work :) If you don't have a 3D printer, I can also print it for you...
https://oscarliang.com/whoopee-micro-frame/

Be aware a few comments below suggest that scaling might be required in some cases (due to shrinkage/printer/filament). Experiment to find good result.

Build example
https://oscarliang.com/whoopee-micro-quad-build-scisky-fc/
http://intofpv.com/t-brushed-evo-f3-eachine-1s-500mah-25c

Discussion:
http://intofpv.com/t-whoopee-micro-quad

It’s not an easy thing to print. I am running a Ultimaker 2+ with Cura. I tried many settings and I have good result with “Normal” printing profile (it takes almost 3 hours to print). It would be even better to go with “Fine” if you can.

Use "Support" "Everywhere", over hang angle 40, I prefer the Line type. Infill density 100%.
Material: PolyMax PLA

It's designed in free 123D Design, so it's probably not perfect.

Example build parts list:

  • FC: Micro Scisky
  • RX: SRP8 PPM Receiver
  • VTX: FX798T
  • Motors: Banggood 0820 Brushed Motors
  • Frame: Whoopee Micro
  • Battery: 380mAh 1S LiPo

Update 03/08/2016

  • Optimized all STL files
  • Added 15 degree VTX mount

Update 06/08/2016

  • fixed problem with 15 degree VTX mount (small gap between bed and object)

Mold for creating a silicone cover insulating the Flexion extruder hotend.

Compared to the heater block insulation that ships with the extruder, this high temp silicon based one should reduce heat transfer to the printed part, should better protect the hotend from the cooling fans, and should prevent printed parts from sticking to the hotend.

In order to make this, you need heat resistant silicone (I bought it on eBay), sandpaper, a bit of duck tape, and two M3 screws and nuts.

Use the mirrored version for the second hotend in the dual extruder version.

Print the three parts (one Hotend part, and two mold parts) Remove the supports. Sand the two other parts so that they fit together snuggly. Use the M3 screws and nuts to fit the two parts together. Insert the hotend part into the mold. The hotend's 'heater cartridge' should fit into the correponding hole in the mold. Remove the Hotend part again. Get the silicone components. Mix the two components; you need enough to fill a bit more than half of the empty mold. Pour the mixed silicone into the empty mould, filling it about halfway. Like this. Tap it against the table a few times to get any bubbles out. Making sure that the heater cartridge fits into the corresponding hole in the mold, push the Hotend part into the mold. The four extrusions from the Hotend part should align with the sides of the mold. Add the remaining silicone on top of the mold, pushing the Hotend part down hard. While pushing the Hotend part down as hard as you can, use duck tape to tape the parts together. Once the silicone has cured, you can remove the screws, and pull the two mld parts off. Note that in the image, there is no silicone below the Hotend part's 'nozzle'. If there is, you dodn't push down hard enough in the last step :-) Once the two mold parts are removed, you can pry the Hotend part out. Be careful not to tear the silicone! After removing the printed parts from the silicone, cut off the extraneous silicone, and cut the holes for the heater cartridge and thermocouple/thermistor open. This mold was made for a Replicator 2, so your printer might need slightly different holes; feel free to edit the OpenSCAD file, or just cut them out of the silicone cover. The final part should look a bit like this. If necessary, remove the extruder from your printer. Remove the heater cartridge and thermocouple/thermistor from your hotend. Slide the heater cartridge and thermocouple/thermistor through the two corresponding holes, and reattach them to the hotend. Carefully slide the silicone cover over your hotend. It should fit snuggly, and stay in place on its own volition. Reattach the extruder to your printer.

description.text:
As part of the thingiverse MakerEd2 Challenge I decided to design a 3D printable clock.

I chose to design a clock which included a wide range of educational functions ranging from teaching children the time, to concepts of stored energy, inertia, gearing, leverage and many of the concepts in Newtonian physics.

As such this clock provides a visual and hands-on demonstration of a wide range of engineering and physics concepts that would be useful in the classroom.
The clock has been designed with ease of construction and cost in mind, as such specialized parts have been kept to a minimum, with the few specialized parts required being easily and cheaply obtainable.

https://youtu.be/G2eVQoxdh_k

Printer:

Wanhao i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Refer to the project text for specific printing settings

After printing it is essential to clean the gears and bearing surfaces with a file or sandpaper. Often when printing the first layers will flatten out creating a lip. If this occurs the clock will not run freely, so all gear teeth should be cleaned and checked for consistency after printing.

Olde-worlde Weight Clock Overview & Background:

This project explores how a mechanical weight powered, pendulum regulated clock operates.

The clock design demonstrates a wide range of physics and mechanical concepts ranging from gear ratios, stored kinetic energy, momentum, inertia as well as clock design and escapement mechanisms, in this case the verge-and-foliot system.

This clock is a fun and safe way to engage students while also teaching them valuable skills and concepts. The clock will also prove useful as learning aid for teaching younger students the time, so has a wide classroom application.

Objectives:

The objective is for students to get hands on experience building a clockwork mechanism and in the process build an understanding of all of the concepts and forces at play behind its operation.

Students should develop an understanding of newtons principals and the three laws of motion throughout this project.

Audiences:

Early secondary school and late primary school students are the target audience for this project. This clock is designed to help students conceptualize Newtons laws of motion through hands on interaction and experimentation with the mechanism.

An approximate class range would be from year levels 6 to 8.

Subjects:

This project would be applicable to physics as well as general science classes in primary and secondary schools.

Skills Learned:

The ability to follow instructions.
Fine motor skills.
Problem solving.
3D printing and slicing.
Group work.
Understanding of the laws of motion.

Lesson/Activity:

This mechanical weight clock has been designed with ease of printing and construction in mind. The design uses a minimum of specialized parts, requiring just 2x paper clips, 4x 12mm countersunk head timber screws, some epoxy glue, 4x M20 stuctural nuts and 9x M14 nuts. All other parts are printed.

All the gear and mechanical components can be printed on the same platter with supports turned on and about 25% infill.

The chassis components can be printed without supports and should for aesthetic reasons be printed in a complimentary colour to the gears. If your printer is not long enough to print the back chassis panel, it can simply be printed in two parts and glued together.

Once the mechanical and chassis components have finished printing it is important to remove the burrs from the gear teeth and bearing surfaces. The easiest way to do this is with a nail file or jewelers file, making sure to clean every tooth on every gear.

Construction starts by assembling the main shaft. The main shaft consists of a 56 tooth gear, three ratchet arms and a 4 toothed gear at the very end. The cord pulley with its ratcheting teeth fits over this shaft and is kept in position by the 26 tooth minute drive gear which slides over the square collar on the main shaft. The raised collar on the minute drive gear should face outward.

The next part to construct is the escapement mechanism. The escapement wheel has 17 lugs and is driven by an 26 toothed gear. To assemble, this press the square end of the escapement shaft into the square cutaway in the escapement wheel, be careful not to break any of the escapement teeth in this process.

The escapement contacts the cams on the escapement shaft which then drives the two horizontal pendulums from side to side. It is the duration of the pendulums to move from side to side that sets the time taken for the escapement to advance one tooth.

The next step is hour hand onto the hour gear, it might be necessary to file the inside of the hand a little in order to make it all fit nicely.

To begin assembly of the main clock start by fitting the minute hand gear through the hole in the front chassis plate and securing it in place with the minute gear carrier. be sure to fit the carrier the right way up as the escapement shaft rides in the hole at the top.

At this stage secure the escapement carrier, if this does not fit in tightly, a little glue can be used to secure it.

Mount the face plate onto the chassis, then fit the hour gear with hand over the bearing collar.

This is a good opportunity to mount the minute hand, as it is easier to apply downward pressure on the shaft in this position.

The next part to assemble into the chassis is the idler shaft. This is a single piece comprised of a 48 tooth gear on one end and 7 teeth on the other. The idler shaft runs off the 56 toothed gear on the main shaft and in turn drives the escapement wheel which is connected to the 48 toothed gear.
Once the idler shaft is fitted into the chassis the main shaft and escapement gear can be mounted onto/into their bearing points.

Mount the top of the chassis onto the chassis back taking care to align all the bearing surfaces. Everything should fit snugly with very little force. Once everything is mounted make sure that everything spins freely, if there is any tightness in the mechanism find which part is the culprit and file/sand it smooth.

Once everything runs freely screw the front down using four 12mm countersunk head timber screws.

Fit the escapement shaft, this slides in on an angle making sure not to damage any of the teeth on the escapement wheel.

Once the escapement shaft is fitted add the pendulum arm.

Now that the clock body is assembled it's time to build the pendulums. The two pendulums consist of two half hemispheres glued together with an M14 nut inside and paperclip loops. These should be printed with supports.

Once the supports have been cut away, unfold and cut two paperclips off at 30mm.

Fit the paperclip loop through the two holes in the top of the pendulum housing and bend the ends over.

Push the bent over ends of the paperclips into the grove, splash some epoxy around and glue both haves of the pendulum over the M14 nut.

Building the counterweight is straightforward, simply scale the STL file to fit your nut diameter, then add 7 M14 nuts and glue the lid on.

Building the main weight is the same process, simply scale the STL file to fit your nut diameters, add the nuts and epoxy the lid on

Before finalizing the clock decided that the clock face looked a little bare, so I printed out some numbers 0.3mm in thickness and stuck to the face. You can design your own using any typeface you like be they numbers or roman numerals, you could even write your numbers on by hand with a marker.

The clock is completed by refitting the face, attaching the pendulums to the pendulum arm and mounting the weights and counterweights using a piece of standard blind cord. The escapement shaft should be suspended by a length of cotton so as to reduce any points of friction.

The main weight should sit to the left, with the counterweight to the right. To rewind the clock simply pull the counterweight down, the ratchet will prevent the clock mechanism from running backward or being damaged.

To calibrate the time simply move the pendulum weights along the arm until you find a position that keeps reasonable time. Obviously this won't keep perfect time, but with proper calibration it can come close.

Duration:

The project will take about 40 hours to print at 50mm/s. and will need to be printed in 3 to 4 batches.

Filing, cleaning and inspecting the gears and bearing surface will take about an hour to complete, but is essential for the smooth running of the clock

Construction should take no more than 2 hours with most of that time being spent gluing the numbers to the clock face as well as assembling the weights and pendulums.

Preparation:

After the parts have been printed they should be carefully cleaned with a sharp hobby knife and a file so as to ensure that there are no lips or excess plastic on any of the gear teeth or bearing surfaces.

The list of printed parts is:

  • Chassis front.
  • Chassis back.
  • Minute gear carrier.
  • Escapement wheel carrier.
  • Clock face.
  • Main shaft.
  • Main shaft ratchet pulley.
  • Main shaft minute gear.
  • Counter-shaft.
  • Minute hand gear.
  • Hour hand gear.
  • Escapement wheel shaft
  • Escapement wheel
  • Escapement shaft
  • Pendulum arm.
  • 2X Pendulum tops
  • 2X pendulum bottom
  • Main weight.
  • Main weight top.
  • Counterweight.
  • Counterweight top.
  • Minute hand.
  • Hour hand.

The non printed parts are:

  • 2x paper clips.
  • 4x 12mm countersunk head timber screws.
  • 5 Minute epoxy glue.
  • 4x M20 stuctural nuts
  • 9x M14 nuts
References:

The best recourse would be the prescribed classroom physics book, as this will include all of the concepts at work within the clock in a format that the students are familiar with.

Wikipedia has some good explanations of the forces at work

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moment_of_inertia

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newton%27s_laws_of_motion

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kinetic_energy

Rubric & Assessment:

By the end of the project:

  • Did the student successfully print all clock components for the model?

  • Did the student assembled the project according to instructions resulting in a working clock?

  • Did the student experiment and calibrate the clock by changing the pendulum positions?

  • Did the student develop an understanding of the principals at work within the clock?

  • Did the student develop an understanding of Newton's laws of motion?

  • Did the student understand the concept of kinetic and stored kinetic energy?

  • Does the student understand how to read the time?

comments.text: Hi,
comments.author: stagbeetle

comments.text:
You're completely right, my naming conventions are terrible, and I'll fix this.
The 'Tack Gear Pins' was something I made up quickly for a person who was having problems with the pins breaking off the escape wheel. I've actually adopted this in my clock now too as the pins are just too fragile when printed. the pins are just little pieces of filament cut to length, then I sand them all to the same level on a flat surface once they are all in place.
Try the 'Escape shaft re exported' stl file as this fixed some of the problems that people were having in cura.
I'll also be adding flatter weights to the design too so that they don't bump into the wall behind the clock when at their outer limits.
comments.author: stagbeetle

comments.text:
Ah, if the pins are 1.75 filament then that's an excellent idea and I'll print the pinless escape wheel. I found the 're-exported' shaft appears fine, it's just the original one looks exactly how I'd expect a pin to look, so I guessed it was jumbled up on uploading.
Just printing the gears in 'gold' colour at the moment,.. I'll upload a 'make' once done... really looking forward to a calm 'ticktock' in the hallway :)
comments.author: retrofluffyboy

comments.text:
Hi,
Thanks so much for this model! I have started printing it. I just wanted to mention that I have been experiencing difficulty slicing many of the parts using Simplify3D - many of the model's parts have errors and do not slice correctly. I was able to repair some of the parts by using the MakePrintable website but not all the parts could be repaired.
comments.author: mselkin

comments.text: Let me know which parts are giving you trouble and I can re-output them with different settings and hopefully fix the problem. I think a few other people had issues with Simplify3D, I never encountered this as I was using Cura.
comments.author: mselkin

comments.text: Hi, I downloaded and tried Cura but some parts still do not work. For example the Escape_Shaft, when loaded into Cura just loads a small tubular structure, 90% of the model is missing. None of the parts will load into Slicr (It just gives an error saying the parts are faulty). Almost all the parts seem to fail where a broad base meets an axle - in Simplify, you can see this after slicing - there is a gap between the part and the axle. The only slicing software I could find that will load the parts is FlashPrint but I would much rather use Simplify3D as it produces the best quality prints for my printer. I have run the parts through the makeprintable web site but that does not repair all of them either.
comments.author: retrofluffyboy

comments.text: I just downloaded the escapement_shaft and it loaded perfectly for me in Cura, but a few other people have reported similar issues to what you are experiencing. One thing which I know will definitely work is to import the STL file into 123D Design, fusion 360, or whichever design program you use, then export it again as a new STL. If this doesn't work for you I'll import the parts that you need into fusion 360 as objects and re export them for you.
comments.author: mselkin

comments.text: Thank you. I shall try that. I am using the mac version of the above programs - not sure if that makes a difference.
comments.author: retrofluffyboy

comments.text: Hi, so sorry to bother you again. Would you be able to re-export just the Escape_Shaft for me?
comments.author: mselkin

comments.text: I've just uploaded it as escapement_shaft_re_export
comments.author: mselkin

comments.text: Thanks so much!
comments.author: retrofluffyboy

comments.text: Let me know if you need any others fixed :-)
comments.author: mselkin

comments.text: Hi, thanks for all your help. I just wanted to share something with others who wish to make this and have difficulty slicing with Simplify3D. The  re-export you did for me still did not work but I discovered that under the advanced tab in the Simplify settings is a "Slicing behaviour" option. If you check the option "merge all outlines into a single solid model", then these parts slice correctly!
comments.author: retrofluffyboy

comments.text:
I'm glad that you found the issue, and I'm sure that it will help others in the same situation. I'd love to see the finished clock, making these models is just something that I do for fun, so I'm glad that other people enjoy them too.
I'll be releasing a modified set of counterweights soon, I've noticed that mine have started to occasionally bump into the wall behind them, So i'll be releasing a more vertical set that should solve this problem.

comments.text: Sorry for the late reply, sometimes there can be a bit of friction between the gears, I actually put a little bit of silicone spray on the bearing surfaces and gave them a good fast spin by hand until they bedded in, you could probably use a cordless drill to spin it till it beds in too. Once that's done it should spin super freely :-)
comments.author: danndayna

comments.text: I'd like to make this. Question: how long does it run on one pull of the weights to the top?
comments.author: rhambus

comments.text:
How long is a piece of string? It depends on how high up the wall you put it and how long you make the string. You can work it out by measuring the circumference of the pulley and dividing your length of string by that distance to work out how many hours it will run for as one revolution of the pulley is equivalent to one hour.
I reset the weights before bed and in the morning or whenever I notice that they are running low, but I get well over 12 hours :-)

En una producción conjunto entre FAB LAB BRC y Bariloche Sustentable, y difundiendo el trabajo de Alejandro Sarmiento, diseñamos esta herramienta mediante tecnología de fabricación digital que genera hilos¨ de plástico a partir de las botellas PET. El plástico PET tiene propiedades de resistencia mecánica, durabilidad, y capacidad de contracción mediante calor, que lo hacen un material sumamente funcional. El objetivo es encontrar nuevas aplicaciones que permitan reutilizar las botellas de gaseosas, siendo consientes que no es una solución definitiva al problema que generan estos desechos pero si una alternativa más. Esperamos que te sumes a la re utilización y puedas encontrar nuevas aplicaciones para compartir los resultados con nosotros vía mail a [email protected] o en nuestro Facebook FAB LAB BRC

In a collaborative production between Bariloche Sustentable and FAB LAB BRC, and disseminating the work of Alejandro Sarmiento, we designed this tool with digital manufacturing technology that produces plastic threads from PET bottles. PET plastics have mechanical strength, durability, and heat-shrinkability, that make it a highly functional material. The goal is to find new applications that allow reuse soda bottles, being aware that it is not a definitive solution to the problem that generate these wastes but yet an alternative. We expect you to join the re use and hope you can find new applications to share with us by mail to [email protected] or in our Facebook FAB LAB BRC

description.text:
This is a toilet flush button (pull type) for an old style toilet. Not really sure what make, possibly "Ifö". There are two variants, one which is pretty plain and one with a bust which might resemble you-know-who.

The design is for an 8.8mm stem with 0.75mm threads, but you may of course change the threads and diameter and other parameters in the OpenScad file.

For very fine pitch threads I suggest you use a layer height of 0.1 mm or less for accuracy.

The head originally comes from here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1023339
Also inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1273176

comments.text: PLA is very resistant to solvents of all kinds. I've used alcohol and e-liquid (e-cig juice) in contact with PLA, and it's very resistant to breakdown. However, I recommend using a stainless or aluminum nozzle and melt chmber if printing something for a food-based application, as brass has trace amounts of lead, which "may" transfer in small amounts to the part you're printing. However, I would suspect that the amount of lead from printing with brass hardware would be practically undetectable.
comments.author: Big-E

comments.text: Does alcohol dissolve PLA over time? It's non-toxic, but I wouldn't want it coloring my drinks.

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:19588
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:34363 size : ?480 x 140 x 70 mm
weight : ?463g
50+ hours printing For some reason, Mr. ErikJDurwoodll didn't have time to finish his awesome Makerlele. Therefore, the main goal of this project is try to combine these 2 parts together, and to make it works. The main part with tuner takes 6 hours for printing, and total duration is about 60 hours. Enjoy and print your own 21" makerlele!

description.text:
This is a remix of the compact bowden extruder by Schlotzz (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:275593). It is intended for a Kossel rig with a top mounted spool. I angled it out since the bowden tube was catching on the carriage pivots. This avoids that problem and also provides a more natural angle for a top feed spool. I also added a mount that can be used to attach a micro switch that can be used for a filament runout sensor. (attach with 2x 2mm or #2 self threading screws). This version is for 1.75mm filament. I may add a 3mm equivalent later, but I don't have Kossel 3mm setup to test it on right now.

I created a newer version in http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2329918

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Just about anything should work.

comments.text: sorry to say, but the design does not work proper. the filament is not running straight, it's bended by the pulley. so there is a lot of "stress" to the whole mechanics and the filament. witchout the pulley the filament still hits the axis of the stepper - not space for the pulley. nice idea, but not really tested.

To avoid the problem you are describing (I think it is the problem you are describing), I added a small pulley that the filament goes around before it enters the extruder. title: Clapton Maker
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Accessoire qui vous permettra de concevoir facilement vos fils en Clapton.

Voici une vidéo qui présente son fonctionnement : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2Z7MtFeiFi8

Ceci est la première version, n'hésitez pas à y apporter des améliorations.

À noter que le Clapton Maker est conçu pour fonctionner avec les bobines de chez Zivipf. Pour l'utiliser avec d'autres bobines, il faudra vous créer un petit tube adaptateur.

Pour les passages pour les câbles, utilisez des pins de résistance pour Protank / Vivi Nova / CE4 (voir dernière photo). Vous devez bien avoir ça quelque part...

Il vous faudra en plus :

  • Environ 40mm de tige filetée
  • 2 écrous M4 (1 à la base et un en contre-écrou pour éviter que ça se desserre quand la bobine tourne)
  • 1 écrou papillon M4 (qui peut être remplacé par un écrou normal)
  • 1 ressort
  • 2 rondelles M4
  • Un peu de Loctite 243 qui empêchera la tige filetée de se desserrer avec l'écrou se situant en bas
  • 3 pins de résistance type Protank 2 / Vivi Nova / CE4

Important : pour un bon fonctionnement, la bobine doit être serrée de façon à ce qu'il y ait une petite résistance lorsqu'on la tourne manuellement.

Bon montage :)

title: RAR Print Double - unic 3D printer with two build platforms

description.text:
The RAR Print Double - unic 3D printer with two build platforms.

Many of you thought about speeding up the process of 3D printing. Perhaps many of yours ideas looks like this. RAR print project bit about something affordable...
Build cost ~ 500 $
TWO build platforms in one frame! Two time faster and smaller than rather 3d printers

More at website: http://rarprint.com/

Today UPDATE:

Files for laser cutting frame rev2
Bill of materials

Features:

Two Printing surface: Left 150x150x150mm. Right 150x150x150mm.
Both Left+Right 300x150x150mm.
Two independing 1.75mm E3D v6 bowden extruders.
Two heated beds.
Glass fiber bed surface, easy to place and remove.
Optional LCD holder (compatible with Smart Controller)

Why?

I was not satisfied with the speed of 3D printing to existing printers, and I decided to make a new one for everybody use. If you unterested in project, stay tuned on my website http://rarprint.com/

independent platforms 3d printing Bracelet 3d printing on double platforms

print_settings.Notes:: Extrusion Width of 0.7mm x 4 = 2.8mm wall

description.text:
The official boxy case for HeaterMeter v4.3 BBQ grill controller. Print your own!

This is customizable case holds a HeaterMeter and Raspberry Pi. Tested with B+ and Pi 3, but should fit A+, B+, Pi 2, Pi 3, and Pi Zero.

Updated:

  • 2018-Feb-02
    • Offset HeaterMeter 1mm from front edge of case
    • Refactored some offsets to use their real-world PCB locations
    • Fix USB pillar reinforcements for walls <2.0mm
    • Decrease size of Pi connector extension 2.0 -> 1.7mm
    • Fix for blocked Pi connector holes on thick walls (1/4")
    • Add keyholes (commented out)
  • 2017-Jun-14
    • Fixed mismatch in depth of bottom screw heads which generated a 0.5mm high piece that cut into cutout
    • LCD mount now scales properly with wall_t thickness
    • Move HeaterMeter up wall/4 to offset it from close wall and allow at least one fill extrusion width on the bottom layer, also should make Base PCB not interact as much on the front left and right corners
  • 2017-Apr-15
    • LCD mount screws returned
    • Added option for no LCD/Button holes (untested)
  • 2017-Apr-11
    • Moved probe centerline up 9.0 -> 9.3, by math
    • Add option for no probe holes at all
    • Mouseears are back! Disabled by default
    • Remove edge stop from Zero variant
    • Remove Pi connector-side hole for 1A+, now is like the old Zero (with SD card ledge and screw landings)
    • Big nut trap ingress height increased by 0.2mm
    • Increased LCD bezel cutout depth by 1mm, grab latch still in the same place
    • Decreased default wall width 3.0mm -> 2.5mm

  • 2016-Nov-23

    • Reduce the size of the Pi right edge stop -0.5mm
    • Nut ingress is now a sideways trapezoid so it starts wider and tapers in, ingress width lowered 5.8->5.7mm
    • Nut recess no longer offset 0.4mm, elongated the points 0.2mm each side.
    • Locklip_p now default inset is 0, only the insert is inset now to allow the base to extend all the way to the wall.
    • Fix microsd being slightly off-center since the case was enlarged last rev.
    • The top of the LCD block is now filleted.

  • 2016-Oct-11

    • Pi PCB was interfering with the USB pillar reinforcements on the bottom
    • Increase locklip_p bar thickness to 2.5mm to allow a more solid fill, body is 0.5mm deeper now (d = d + 0.5)
    • Reduce top negative body inset chamfer, this didn't seem to make any difference in warping and takes longer / more material to print.
    • Add vertical internal body corner fillets to the top two corners to let them get filled while printing. Bottom two need to be square still.
    • Reduce length of front guide lip to prevent possible interference with mcu socket if overextruded.
  • 2016-Oct-05
    • Adds configurable parameters for corner radius and chamfer height. Corner radius must be > 0 even if it is 0.01.
    • Adds configurable parameters for wall thickness and face thickness
    • Adds new Pi style Connectorless which is for a Pi 2 or 3 with the USB and Ethernet covered.
    • Removes mouseears.
    • Default wall thickness is now 3mm (up from 2.82mm).
  • 2016-Sept-23
    • Replace square edge fillets with new continuous bead chamfer and increase roundness of corners
    • Fix guide lips not being attached in STL export
    • Added USB pillar reinforcements
    • Reduce wall thickness 0.14mm (2.82mm now)
    • Interior filleted to add corner strength
    • Case split at different height for probe vs rest of case to mabe USB pillars less torqueable
  • 2016-Sept-16 - Adds optional corner mouseears
  • 2016-Sept-09 - Adds additional lips on sides to aid in alignment

Printer:

C-Bot

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Do not print with support, no angle is greater than 45 degrees and support could fill the nut traps which would make then really hard to clean out.

Be sure your slicer fills the posts between the USB jacks and the locklip with something (infill or solid) or they will be brittle.

Walls should be an even multiple of extrusion width to be solid. Examples:

  • Extrusion Width of 0.7mm x 4 = 2.8mm wall
  • Extrusion Width of 0.7mm x 2 + External Perimeters 0.6mm x 2 = 2.6mm wall
  • Perimeters 0.5mm x 4 = 2.0mm wall or 0.5mm x 6 = 3.0mm wall

Hardware

Attach both halves together with 2x M3 nuts and 2x M3 socket cap screws, 25mm-30mm.

The case has a feature to help align the nuts. Insert them into their holes from the side until they jiggle freely (a small screwdriver can help them get into the cavity). Before closing the case, insert your bolt down into the nut and tighten it a few turns. Press down to trap the nut in the tighter recess below the slot (see the cutaway image above) until it snaps into place. Then back out the screw and it will remain aligned with the screw hole. Keeping the case tilted so that the probe side is up also helps to prevent them from wiggling out of alignment before you can get the screws in.

description.text: Being the Halloween season Mr. Octopus decided he would like to dress up.  He thought a truly fitting Halloween costume might be a pumpkin.  Being a good Octopi keeper, I whipped out openscad and attempted to work some model merging and deference lovin and the Pumpkin Costume for Octopus was born!

Pumpkinpus.stl is an untested design. I think it will print, but I'm a little worried about the back of the pumpkin where the back of the octopus hangs out causing an overhanging area in the back might not print so well. I Have however successfully printed the pumpkinpuswithback.stl and seems to work fine. I did have a little issue in the mouth area but still turned out fine. Settings I used are as follows.
layer_height = 0.25
perimeters = 2
top_solid_layers = 4
bottom_solid_layers = 4
fill_density = .2

title: 3D Hidden Maze (3x3x3 or 4x4x4)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a 3D puzzle cube. In the cube is an hidden 3D maze. The idea is to get a ball from entrance A to exit B.

Customise maze

In the files section there is a .STL file for a design for a 8.5mm ball. If you want to use another ball size you can customise the OpenSCAD file and tune the parameters for your needs.

Create your own maze

With the included OpenSCAD file it is possible to make your own maze. In the file there is an table where you can define, for each point in the cube, the direction where the ball can go. You need to use the following variables:

  • mx = -x direction
  • px = +x direction
  • my = -y direction
  • py = +y direction
  • mz = -z direction
  • pz = +z direction
  • nn = no entry

description.text:
Pointy Haired Boss from the comic strip 'Dilbert' by Scott Adams.

In the comic strip, the Pointy Haired boss provides a fountain of wisdom, which you need to avoid at all costs.

No supports are required. If you have the right filament colors, no painting is needed.

The completed model is 200mm tall after assembly. This model is in proportion to the Dilbert model previously posted as http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1689535

Enjoy!

Printer:

FlashForge Creator X

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

See below for tips in preparing the model for assembly

Colors (there are no multiple printed pieces)

Following are the colors that I used:
..
Beige/Skin:
boss_head
boss_hand_right
boss_hand_left
..
Black:
boss_shoe_right
boss_shoe_left
boss_hair
boss_tie_a
boss_tie_c
boss_tie_e
boss_tie_g
boss_eye_left
boss_eye_right
..
Blue:
boss_jacket
boss_arm_left
boss_arm_right
boss_pants
boss_tie_b
boss_tie_d
boss_tie_f
..
White
boss_shirt
boss_sleeve_right
boss_sleeve_left

Printing and assembly tips

Printing Tips:
1-No special printing tips are needed, other to make sure that the first layer squish (if you have one) is completely cleaned off any piece that may seem not to fit. As I put mine together I thought that I had a design issue with two pieces but in both cases I simply did not clean the first layer well enough (I am terrible at leveling my printer).
..
2-Just like in my Dilbert model, since the tie is made up of smallish pieces, people with 'fat fingers', like myself, might make a mess when gluing the pieces of the tie together. I decided (based on my wife's suggestion) to include a small hole through all the tie pieces to help in positioning them while gluing. I pushed a piece of slightly sanded 1.75mm filament through all the pieces to help position them as I glued one at a time. Stringing the tie pieces together is not required, just possibly more convenient for some people
..
Assembly tips
-The diagram below will help in assembling the model.
-The model is meant to be glued together.
-The shirt needs to be snapped in through the jacket. Clean the first layer of the shirt thoroughly first.
-The socks are part of the shoes and should fit into the jacket almost fully. Again, be sure to clean the hole for the socks, which is the first layer of the jacket.
-Since the eyebrows/eyes are small, the holes in the head can be considered more as a placement guide than actually fitting snugly in. Clean off as much of the first layer brim as you can, concentrating on the spot between the eye and the eyebrow to ensure the eye is more rounded. When gluing, press on the eye portion, the eyebrows are supposed to be a bit bushy and stick out more than the eye. This is a minor detail and noted just to avoid any frustration or confusion during the build.
-Assembling the model is straight forward. Just be sure to glue all of the tie pieces together to create the full tie separately. I suggest attaching the completed tie to the rest of the model as the last step.

Pointy Haired Boss Assembly

comments.text: Is this model in the same scale as Dilbert?  Started printing him at the 150% I did with Dilbert and it looks like it is going to be much larger.  Could just be because his waist line is a lot bigger.
comments.author: ElmoC

comments.text: All models are scaled to the original Dilbert.  Pointy Haired Boss is simply rounder. Be careful with the shirt fitting into the jacket.  It is a snug snap fit to start with, I hope resizing does not cause issues (might make it an easier fit though)
comments.author: ElmoC

comments.text: I'll let you know how the fitting goes. The blue is taking about 17 hours.
comments.author: reddadsteve

comments.text: I assume that when you say the blue is 17 hours, that you can fit both pieces at the same time.  I threw just the jacket in my slicer at 150% and with two shells and 10% infill my estimate was 8 hours, both pieces showed 18 hours but would not fit on my printer.
comments.author: ElmoC

comments.text: My print bed is 300x200 and I can fit all the blue pieces on it.  S3D gave an estimate of 12 hours and 21 minutes.  Of course, those are never that accurate.  It has been running 14 hours now.  I am using a Duet 0.8.5 controller and the web interface is showing an estimate of another 3 to 4 hours.  Those estimates are normally pretty good this far into a job.
comments.author: reddadsteve

comments.text: I can't make my printer go fast enough! Done with white and black. Working on Blue now. Go go go go go go. :)
comments.author: baldengineer

comments.text: In the world of 3D printing, slow and steady wins the race!  I got an email from someone who left her printer running overnight printing the pants and woke up to the biggest pile of spaghetti strings I've ever seen.
comments.author: baldengineer

comments.text:
OMG my lists of "projects to print" and "projects to assemble" gets even longer ...
could you please develop a little bit slower (just kidding!) ... ;-))
comments.author: BerndJM

comments.text: The Pointy Haired Boss was comparatively easy once I had Dilbert completed, therefore the short turn around time.  Hopefully you catch up a bit before my next 'challenge project'!
comments.author: BerndJM

comments.text: I apologize for any inconvenience, boss_shoe_right was loaded incorrectly.  The file has been updated.
comments.author: reddadsteve

title: Tevo Tarantula Dual PLA FAN with SN-04 Sensor

description.text:
I was so happy to received that brand new printer kit, it even came with autolevel sensor!... but... no bracket to mount it!!???!!?

So I look online, and I finish by designing one that fits my needs.

Compact, Pla fan and sn-04 sensor. design to work with original fan (30mm) and dual head, it look good :)... and a bonus is that it work well too!!

I've add the FreeCAD file so you could play with it... (I would release a version for volcano head shortly (when my friend received it :) )

I print it on the side with no support ... would test your bridge but not that much

Enjoy!!

comments.text: Is there any way you could make this work with 40mm fans? I love the design just like the 40mm silent fans that I have and would like to use them.
comments.author: robmcqueen

comments.text: what model of fans are used ? i just waiting for my tarantula and i want to be ready when it came
comments.author: bezdomny

comments.text: I use the original fan that comes with the printer and another of the same dimension (by memory it's a 30mm)
comments.author: bezdomny

comments.text: Normally, I jog my nozzle to made it touching the build plate, I used an 1.5 mm thick rule as spacer to have the correct offset for my sensor and set it in place (so my sensor is level and 1.5mm higher than my nozzle) ... and play with the firmware z offset until I reach wanted result...

comments.text: What are you doing to set your level sensor height,  been fighting with mine a lot, directions say 2mm but i cant seem to get it set in the right spot for repeatable startups.

description.text: Complex and a little naughty, this cane handle was printed in PLA with a 0.39 nozzle and 0.15 pass. It makes a strong cane handle and when combined with a 1" dowel and a rubber tip makes a light strong cane with a touch of worldly class.

You will need support  there is a lot of overhang. Give it 4 coats of clear acrylic paint. I use gorilla grip glue to attach the 1" hardwood dowel and some stain for the wood. And you'll have a strong light cane with a touch of old world charm.

title: Adjustable feet & endcap for 20x20x2 mm square tube

description.text:
Adjustable (machine) feet for 20x20x2 mm square tube. Ideal to get things level on the floor.

I've also included end caps without the thread in it. They can be used for protection or just looks.

I've used it on a shoe rack I made out of metal tubing.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

20-80 %

Notes:

I printed the adjustable ones in pla with a 0.15 resolution 3 perimeters and 25% infill and this gave good results. You can increase the infill and perimeters if they turn out to be too weak for your application.

The endcaps without screws are printed in grey pla at the same resolution but with 2 perimeters and 10 percent infill.

title: Dell Notebook Power Supply Strap Pin

description.text:
The pin that holds the cable organizer strap on the PS is really fragile. Yours broke ?
Don't worry just print this replacement one.

Print file DellStrapPin.stl for a single copy or DellStrapPin2x.stl for a table of two (next time it breaks you already have a backup !)
Thanks for tinkercad.com for making the design process so easy and enjoyable

description.text:
Yes. It's a unipegataur... wizard.

This character was designed for our sci-fantasy tabletop RPG, Wayfarer: Things Beyond Wonder and for our modular wargaming system, Wayfarer Tactics. If you want to print a 28mm scale version, just scale it up by 180%. A viewable render is available via Sketchfab.

We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...)

Enjoy!

description.text:
The folding arms always caused me problems on my Hovership, if I crashed or landed hard, the front would fold in so I would have to go pick it up and straighten out the arms again, and furthermore, the arms were never evenly spaced (not extended equally) causing problems with flying. This makes the frame more rugged and symmetrical without having to worry about the arms folding and shifting, but sacrificing portability.

I also changed up the design slightly and made the holes in the plate bigger to accommodate my larger ESC's. This is the first design and I worked for me, but if you print this and have problems with its functionality or durability, please let me know in the comments so I can approve upon the design for the community.

print_settings.Notes:: scale the object to 50% for the token to be accurate.

description.text:
This is my lame attempt to make a 3D encounter token to use with Jamey Stegmaier's amazing new tabletop game, Scythe. The game comes with so many beautiful components that it seemed a shame to use any standard cardboard pieces on the board at all. This is my attempt to address that.

When I printed these, I swapped out the PLA just as it started the top layers of the piece so that I wouldn't have to paint them at all. I had some gnarly issues with spiderwebs, leading to an hour or so of me picking at the tokens with an exacto to clean them up, but I'd say it was worth it. They serve their purpose, even if they don't do justice to the rest of the game's incredible design. Thank you, Jamey, for an incredible gaming experience!

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

High

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I swapped out the PLA just as it started the top levels of the token so that the compass meridian and outside circles would be a highlighted color. I used True Green for the base and True Yellow for the highlight color.

It's important to know that when you import the STL file, you will need to scale the object to 50% for the token to be accurate.. Sorry, I'm new at this, and I didn't want to go back and figure out what I did wrong with the sizing.

I used Google Sketchup to throw this quick design together. If anyone has issues with the model, I apologize in advance; I did my best to try to replicate what was printed on the game's token pieces to the best of my ability, and occasionally used some "creative" methods to accomplish what I did. It wouldn't surprise me to find out that I had messed up the model in some way!

remixed_from.author: Skimbal
remixed_from.title: Christmas Lego Men of Kansas City

description.text: A Blank MiniFig. Scaled to 4x normal size. Optimized to be printed on a Desktop 3D Printer, and extensively tested. This will serve as the bases for a series of upcoming derivatives. So hold onto you butts...

Snap_Hips.stl and Blank_Head.stl need to be printed with support material. Hands
Press the hands into the hand holes in the arms. Attach the Arms to the Body
Press the snap pins out through the Body's arm holes, then press the Arms onto them. A pair of pliers can be useful for locking the snap pins into place. Legs
Snap the Legs onto the Hips, and press the Hips into the Body. Head
Press the head onto the Body.

title: Customizable Gear or double gear (V pattern) with optional pivot

description.text:
This is something I grabbed from an OpenSCAN library file and customized it and added a few features. I also correct an alignment issue in the example in the file.

I didn't clean up the comments in the file yet. I changed the code only so far.

You can create one or two gears. The two gears are in a V or chevron pattern. You can reverse direction of the pattern, change the angle of the teeth and change the pivot radius (or omit it all together). You can also create a hole of any size too.

description.text:
I recently designed a new series of Pocket-Tactics models meant to print standing without supports (though support may help a bit, depending on your printer calibration) and we abandoned this style in favor of a new one for the next edition (coming soon!). The models go well with our regular 18mm range, so I decided I should go ahead and post them for you rather than just let them go to waste. As with the other 18mm stuff, if you want a 28mm version, increase the size by 166.6% (that'll get you to a 25mm base and the correct model proportions).

We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...)

Enjoy!

description.text: This is an underwater noisemaker for communicating while scuba diving. I simply start the print and after the wall is formed up about an inch, I drop in a couple of 1/4 20 nuts. Anything heavy enough to shake should work, but I had these in my basement. The loop on top should attach to a small carabiner or to a key-chain Alternatively, tie some cord and attach it wherever is convenient and safe. I print it solid for strength and water-tightness.

You can brush it with acetone, if printing in ABS, paint or smooth it, or use it as is.

comments.text: Hello Limolwali! Nice idea!  What filament did you use to print this with? How has it held up in saltwater?  I'm curious if you've had any compression or weakening issues at depth? Apologies for "flooding" you with questions. LOL
comments.author: HalfOgre

comments.text: I used ABS. It has help up remarkably well...even in saltwater. In fact, it shows no signs of deterioration at all. I don't think I've done any dives below 100ft with it, but structurally, there are no signs of weakness. That's probably because the design is essentially an arch in every direction. However, I would recommend making it a little longer and using a couple of heavier weights in it, both to make it louder and to keep it from floating up while attached to your BCD. I may modify it and repost with a couple of changes if I decide to make another.
comments.author: HalfOgre

comments.text: Thanx! Good luck and safe diving!

title: Ord Hadron X Carriage with Integrated single/dual e3d mount

description.text:
I created this thing to simplify mounting an e3d hotend to my ord hadron. Rather than drill holes and inevitably get the placement wrong, I decided to integrate the x carriage with the hotend mount. This configuration ensures perfect perpendicular alignment of the hotend to the X extrusion. I recommend that anyone printing this should go ahead and splurge on new eccentric spacers (the spacers with the extended boss) - the extended boss is thick enough to go all he way through the plastic carriage (specifically designed for this type of carriage): https://www.inventables.com/technologies/eccentric-spacer Added v5 versions (single and dual) with mount hole spacing to match this new GT2 belt clamp thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:184634/#files Added v3 versions (single and dual hotend) with a surface for mounting an LED strip at the bottom (see pics) Added version 4 dual extruder files - minor adjustment in spacing between hotends to allow for "beefier" fan shrouds and more space for cable mounting. In action: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GkgHiW46QAk
In action: http://youtu.be/LwZuEmkql2c Updated - added single hotend with and without the ord carriage 90 degree bench, and an experimental dual hotend configuration. I've just orded my second bowden-based e3d hotend, so I've yet to test the dual hotend configuration. updated - added a second (v2) dual hotend configuration that should bring both hot ends as close as possible together. updated -added a third (v3) dual hotend configuration that includes extensive reinforcement and removal of pre-defined holes (drill your own). Also added (v3) single hotend with reinforcement and "drill your own" harness mount points. I borrowed directly from:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:128109
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:148536
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9742
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:128900

Drill out bolt holes connecting the collar pieces to the main plate so that you drill back beyond the nut trap, into the rectangular block. The bolt hole does not extend far enough and this was created by combining objects, so the rectangular block does not have the bolt hole extended. You will need the following for the mount collar, per hotend:
2 M3 x 30'ish bolts
2 M3 jam nuts
One collar print per hotend, the single or the dual collar. To use the .scad files, you'll need to update the import() statement to reference a copy of the following:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:128109 for Version 5 carriages, use version 4 collar.

comments.text: In my opinion you shouldn't print E3D mount as a one piece with whole carriage. And you should add some kind of support below a E3D mount (simple triangle should be ok)
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I disagree that any additional support is needed. In any groove mount assembly, the collar is all that should and does hold the hotend, either to the ectruder assembly (which in turn is attached to the carriage) or, in this case, directly to the carriage.  Since this is a bowden implementation, the carriage is only a hotend mount.  I don't believe the e3d hotend differs from a j-head in that respect.

author: dutchmogul

print_settings.Notes:: The 0.1mm resolution is important with these. They're only 0.7mm tall, so if you try to print them at any lower resolution I can promise they will not turn out. Perfect or near perfect calibration and leveling of your printer is a must with these.

description.text:
Those little cardboard NuYen that come with Shadowrun Clossfire sure are easy to lose, aren't they? I've lost enough of them that it's not uncommon to run low on 1 NuYen pieces during a game. Plus I think they'd look better printed as gold coloured plastic than printed on cardboard.

I printed two runs of 36 each of the 1 NuYen pieces. I didn't print any 5 NuYen pieces because in my experience the only time they get used is when we run out of 1 NuYen pieces, which I don't foresee being a problem any more. Anyway the only difference between the two runs is that the one on the top in the pictures was printed with concentric fill and the one on the bottom was printed with rectilinear fill. Both are the same picture, one with flash and one without because the flash flooded out the details.

I had some rejects in both runs. My printer isn't perfectly calibrated and at less than 1mm high these things are NOT forgiving of less than perfect first layers. The rectilinear fill had much higher success though, with only 3 rejects as compared to 9 with the concentric fill.

description.text: customized with 3D Slash! for my tabletop game.

This "backpack" is two parts that snap together to hold a LiPo battery to the back of a Circuit Playground board.

There is clearance between the backpack and the board so you can still clip on to any of the pads. The posts that clip to the board are small and spaced so they won't obstruct any pads either.

This is a really secure little assembly, and great for holding your battery to your project. If your printer isn't good at small overhangs, you might consider using minimal supports - the locations should be pretty easy to clean.

description.text: bale wrapper for diorama

This is a remix of the EZ-Snap Razor Blade Handle by AdanA. It has been adapted for classic double-edged (Gillette) safety razor blades. These are only 0.1mm thick and slip under prints very easily. You won't be able to lift any prints with such a blade except very small ones, but you can use the clearance to shove a thicker and larger blade or plastic sheet under the print, and easily remove it from the platform. This also works very well to remove skirts and any other small bits stuck to the platform. Just be careful to keep the blade at a low angle to avoid digging it into softer build surfaces like BuildTak.

Update 2016/08/07: uploaded version 2 of the model, which has a larger tab that offers a more secure mount for the blade, allowing to push harder on the blade without bending it.
Update 2016/10/05: uploaded version 3 of the model, which has an even larger tab and also a slightly taller structure to hold the blade in place. This version has less risk of the blade slipping out when it gets caught under a print. (I kept v2 available for those who prefer the extra bit of flexibility in the razor blade.)

I recommend printing this at 0.1mm layer height to ensure that the subtle recess that prevents the blade from moving around, comes out right, and the tab to secure the blade will fit correctly. If the tab would be too loose, add sheets of adhesive tape to its underside until it is snug.
An optional cap is included (you can print this at any reasonable layer height).

Of course: be careful especially while mounting the blade, those blades are very sharp. I recommend using the edge of a table to push the tab in the slot, so you don't need to come near it with your fingers.

title: Venom 75 Folding Micro Quad Frame
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
So this is clearly inspired by the Foldable Brushed Microquad by ulflindestrom (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1604440), but here it's been totally remade from scratch for 6mm motors, Hubsan FC, and Eachine H8 Mini (45mm) props. At 75mm folded out, it's one of the smallest micros I've ever heard of! Not sure how big folded up, but it certainly ought to fit in your pocket.
Enjoy!

UPDATE 9:07PM 8/2/16: Added 7mm motor mounts for many who requested them :) make sure to cut your props to 45mm though or this won't work. I'm not sure if you can just do that and have it work but I have loads of extra Hubsans so I'll try it.

UPDATE 11:07PM 8/2/16: Cut some Hubsans to 45mm with nail clippers, a Sharpie, and a ruler. They fit well and I balanced them with a needle and some magnets. They seem to do okay... Haven't flown them yet (obviously) but they were easy to mod.

UPDATE 11:33PM 8/2/16: Made each plate 4mm longer so that the arms fold in more flush with the body than before. Not a big deal but since I'm so friggin OCD I literally couldn't sleep thinking about it...

UPDATE 8:30PM 8/3/16: RobQuarters brought it to my attention that the motor mounts were just too tight for the motors to fit in there, so I made them all 0.25mm larger. I also labelled everything "xxxx_v2" because I have changed little things along the way so this is to clarify that. The plates are the same as they were yesterday at 11:33PM.

UPDATE 1:19PM 8/4/16: At the request of tomoquads, I added some 8.5mm mounts.

UPDATE 12:29PM 8/7/16: Made some better mounts. Made them all .3mm larger than the intended motor size to fit perfectly. Also added 2 plates to fit a Scisky FC.

As with ulflindestrom's design, use 4 M3 screws and nuts (I recommend nylon for weight) to hold it together. I also recommend Eachine H8 Mini props, a Hubsan X4 FC, and some Eachine (cuz they're cheap) 150mAh or larger batteries. You can glue on LEDs too if you like but at this size, that's usually unnecessary weight.

I looked at ulflindestrom's design and decided a 6mm for the Tiny Whoopers out there might be fun, plus my old 6mm Hubsan died ;(, so I have some time to waste waiting for parts. Basically just spent 3 hours giving myself a headache (thanks TinkerCAD) but at least it seems worth it ;)

title: Kite Messenger
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I have had a soft spot for kites since I've been a kid. I remember seeing these kite messengers or ferrys like this at kite festivals years ago. This is a kite messenger based on erwinha's Kite messenger 1.2. Big thanks to Erwin for helping me out with this project.

It sped up the line on it's first test and works great. Honestly, the hardest part of this project was sewing the sail. See in action here. This is still a work in progress, I will probably make more revisions as I get more flight time with this model.

Printing

Both messenger body parts (front and back) were printed with MakerGeek's PLA. Use rafts for the back piece. Went pretty heavy with the infill on these parts because they receive a lot of the punishment. 4 shells with 45% infill.

For all the pushrod, center spar holder and spring stop parts i chose to use NinjaTek's Semiflex filament. I love the way this stuff prints, it's strong and flexible. The outer piece of the center spar holder was printed in PLA. Their print grains are opposite one another to provide better strength (was not sure how much twisting and torquing this piece would receive under a load). 4 shells with 20% infill.

Materials and Assembly

Messenger Body
8mm OD carbon tube 5.75mm ID x 60cm length.
This must be a hollow tube in order to house the pushrod for the lock mechanism

Messenger Pushrod
1/8-in Brass Metal Round
Pushrod 67.65cm
Locking rod 39.5mm
These are rough measurements. The idea is to leave just enough play in the pushrod for the locking rod to clear the opening without leaving the back part of the lock.

Rollers
I chose to go with a cheap 1-in Dia Vinyl Sliding Screen Door Nylon Bottom Roller Assembly kit that I found at Lowes. Just gave it a bit of graphite to help reduce friction.

Center Spar Sleeve
Used short 7mm piece of 7/32" Round Brass Tube to sleeve the top sail spar with the center spar connector. Thought it would provide less friction than the ninjaflex would.

Sail and Spars
Used 4.75mm solid fiberglass round for both spars. I only bought a yard of ripstop nylon so my sail is roughly 36" wide and 36" tall. I trimmed the spars to length once the sail was complete.

Stop plates and Spring Stop
Cut up a wire clothes hanger to use as a line anchor to stop the messenger at either end of it's travels. the plate will take a counter sunk screw (Not sure of the size just used what i had lying around). I found a 3/4" x 3-1/2" compression spring at the hardware store to soften the messenger when it comes back down the line. The messenger spring stop should fit snug inside the spring after you feed it on the line.

comments.text: Nice design. Have you occasionally got 3d model of the yellow spool which is on the first picture? I love it and would use it for my kite.

comments.text: The yellow spool you are asking about is just a standard 10" YoYo kite line winder. They are pretty cheap and come in a variety of sizes. Unfortunately, I don't have a model of one. To be honest i don't know if I would trust a 3d printed spool with a 1000 ft of line wrapped around it under tension. If it split it would make for one heck of a rat's nest of line to untangle.

description.text:
Uploaded 08-02-2016
Update Pictures! 08-03-2016

Coming Soon: Assembly update

The perfect fit for those looking to expand their print bed and not the extrusion carriage on the classical Prusa I3 base model. Using Mak-a-faces (& MiguelPyntos Remix) clever and compact design, I based an entirely new compact direct drive extruding system to compliment his design. Runnig into ascetic problems I decided to throw this .stl file into Tinkercad (one of the only places that lets you edit .stl files) and flange out the sides to accomodate for my extruder!

The Carriage itself holds three LM8UU linear ball bearing very firmly, while letting a small amount of play between jogging left and right. this carriage looks and works well with a custom direct drive extruder. The Gt2 Belt grips are spot on accurate (as long as your printer is accurate ; ) and will not need any assistance holding them even when moving at speed greater than 200mm/s. The belt also has a sleek wrap around, fitting the unconnected side very nicely into the part.

author: dalefukami

title: Premier League Trophy - Just the Lions for the handles
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
@Badgerous did an awesome job of the trophy and it prints excellent, so rather than reinvent the wheel I took the Lions from a trophy I made in Blender so you can add them to your scene when you print.

You will need to adjust the scale to match the cup. I suggest adding the cup and lions, getting the scale right and then deleting the cup. You will need to print the lions lay down (on their side) and use supports.

Enjoy, and kudos to @Badgerous for the original model.

Trophy here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1380509

G2S Pro
